Award.AwardTitle: Effects of Computer Support for Collaborative Learning in STEM Education: A Research Synthesis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a project to review and synthesize the research literature on Computer Supported Collaborative Learning (CSCL) conducted between 2005 and 2012. The project team will identify major themes in the research results; analyze effects on learning outcomes in CSCL research; identify moderating factors and trends; synthesize major lessons learned; and identify important gaps that still exist in our knowledge. Automated data mining and text analysis will be used to validate results.

The project should result in a framework for studying CSCL as well as an empirically-grounded set of design principles for how CSCL should be used in different educational settings, whether in or out of the classroom. Given the fast pace of development in the use of technology to support STEM learning, this synthesis should help give a broader historical context in which to understand them as well as encourage more directed and targeted research and development in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project began with four main goals. First, to describe and synthesize the research findings of Computer-Support Collaborative Learning (CSCL) research in STEM education. Secondly, to construct a conceptual and analytical framework for comparison across CSCL studies that would help us determine how, why, and when CSCL is effective. Third, to identify gaps in the existing knowledge base. Finally, to disseminate our findings to help guide both future CSCL research as well as to assist teachers in their application of CSCL in classrooms. 

The project initially screened over 1,600 articles published between 2005-2014 that studied the effect of CSCL and synthesized from 708 studies to include in the meta-synthesis and a subset of these to use in a meta-analysis. Initial results suggested that multiple forms of CSCL are practiced in STEM fields. With this in mind, we chose to use broad definitions of both CSCL and our measures of its effectiveness. 

Intellectual Merit: Our analysis showed a substantive effect of CSCL in educational research and demonstrates an overall positive effect of CSCL in STEM education. This effect is influenced by the domains of learning CSCL is used in, as well as the technology employed, and the pedagogies explored in its application. These three factors can be used as a framework to examine the effectiveness of CSCL in STEM education. It also showed that a great deal of CSCL has been devoted to supporting inquiry learning, largely in face-to-face settings for K-12 learners and in asynchronous settings with adult learners.  

Key to success across of CSCL across many contexts, pedagogical models, and technologies is the importance of structure and feedback.  Among others, two major gaps were identified in existing knowledge base of this topic that we believe merit further exploration. First is the role of peer feedback. The examined studies often reported details of the role of teachers and technology but less so on the role of peer feedback and providing explicit supports for that. Second, with the increasing sophistication of learning analytics, we would like to see more adaptive CSCL environments examined closely in the future. In addition to this, this synthesis suggests an important role for professional development.

As part of this synthesis, Jeong and Hmelo-Silver (2016) developed a framework for identifying different functions that CSCL environments need to support for effective collaborative learning. CSCL technologies are embedded in environments that provide different affordances for learning and shared meaning-making. This framework addresses particular kinds of functions that learners need or challenges that learners face in CSCL settings. Affordances refer to the ways that technology can provide opportunities for particular kinds of functions that mediate learning. CSCL technologies provide learners opportunities to (1) engage in a joint task, (2) communicate, (3) share resources, (4) engage in productive collaborative learning processes, (5) engage in co-construction, (6) monitor and regulate collaborative learning, and (7) find and build groups and communities.

Our synthesis has suggested that for CSCL technology to be effective in STEM classrooms, there must be properly prioritized instructional goals. Our hope is that these findings can guide research and practice toward examining appropriate combinations of technology, pedagogy and modes of collaboration. Further, we hope that teachers will be able to use this study's findings to remain flexible in their application of pedagogical and technological tools in order to achieve instructional success. Our study can help to provide an understanding of how a given technology, in combination with certain pedagogies, can be used to achieve that success and make teachers more effective in helping students meet the demands of the world in which collaboration is becoming ever more important.
